Notes:

I printed mine with 4 walls and 20% infill.
This gear fits on a canon 50mm 1.8 ef lens so you can use a follow focus.

This is a frame I designed using Tinkercad. It is designed for curved lithophanes made from square pictures. I make the lithophane by going to this website http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/ and use model size of 100 mm with a 3mm frame. When the model is curved then the STL object will have the size of X=21.6mm, Y=94.0mm, Z=100mm and I position it along the Y direction on the bed for better quality. For the frame I recommend infill 25% or greater. (I like 35%).
There is file for a box lid with 1 pic, and also a lid for a frame with 2 pics. They are really interchangeable so you can use whichever one you like better.
There is a hole 8.5mm in diameter needed for a typical power plug of 5.1mm x 2.1mm. I like to use a short LED strip of 6 to 9 LED's with a 12V DC power adapter. This way the entire assembly can be used as a nite-light that uses 1W to 1.5W only.
I have other designs which I should upload soon, one for a simple base to be used with candle light, one that's for flat lithophanes (100mm x 100mm) and one for RGB LED's that has a base large enough to contain a small microcontroller circuit to control the color etc.

comments.author: venuasg

comments.text: This is because the original picture used is not square. I am going to add a new design for models based on pictures that have an aspect ratio of 4:3 instead of 1:1 but I have not had a lot of free time to do it yet, it will be soon. Cropping the picture to make it square can be done with any image editing software like Windows Paint or Photoshop etc. For example if your picture is 1200 x 900 pixels it is a 4 to 3 aspect ratio. So you can crop it with your software and make it 900 x 900 for example. Then the printed model will fit inside the frame fully. If you use the 3dp.rocks program with a 1200x900 picture and set maximum size to 100 mm, then it will make the longer side of the picture equal to 100 mm and the shorter side will be proportionally shorter, so 75 mm.

title: Spring load Y axis, anet A8, Prusa I3

description.text:
i heard about spring load axis for CNC machine. so i decided to create my own version for my 3d printer.
it will decrease the vibration of the belt and keep the tension even at any moment.

the spring i use is the standard bed level spring (7MM). later i found out it will not be enough if you have a heavy bed like my. so i used a extra pen spring and if you can use a powerful spring i will recomend you to use it.
i used a long M3 screw (52MM) and its nut.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50

Notes:

look like the 3d printer hinge will not hold the weight but it will, or at less if you print with ABS like i did.
in case you want to to play save i include a strongest pulley arm.

do not be afraid of the tension

you will have to print a couple cube tests to find the correct tension. and when you find it, i recommend to increase a little bit more just to be sure.

why

i wanted to see if it will increase the quality of the print and i have to say it will, but not expect much, a correct level bed and a good setting will do more. but if you like perfect print you could try it.

title: X-Axis Parts for Zaribo and Prusa MK2(S)

description.text:
UPDATE 26.02.2018: The following files have been upated

x-MotorHolder-1x-2.1
x-Idler-1x-2.1
x-BeltTensioner-Part2-1x-2.1
x-BeltTensioner-Part1-1x-2.1

NOTE: The pulley needed is a 16T (the stock one is 20T)

There was a mix-up o files with different depth of holes for the rods. And an easier to print belt tensioner has been introduced.

This is the new x-axis for Zaribo Rel 2.0 ☺️ The parts are 100% compatible with Prusa MK2(S). After redesigning the belt now runs parallel and has no more tilting issues.

Thanks to Jon Madden for his great idea with belt tensioner and his work on the x-carriage.

For the MK2 there are no more zip-ties on the back of the carriage. The x-carriage features a new way of fastening the belt.

The new x-motor holder has some new features

  • supported holder for the threaded rods
  • two little "windows" on the back to check proper rod insertion
  • a little cutout makes rods insertion much easier without any drilling. It prevents filament from "falling down" during printing and making the holes a bit smaller
  • a new way for cable management.

Original parts by Jon Madden: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2770019 and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2770105

More information on Zaribo can be found on http://zaribo.org/ or on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/groups/284271408664100/?ref=bookmarks

An approximate model of the old college football BCS trophy / the current Coaches' Trophy. The model is true-to-life sized at 34" tall for the entire trophy, while the crystal football itself is 12" long.

MAJOR NOTE: My 3D printer is out of commission, so I have not attempted to print this myself (yet). If there are issues outside of the obvious size and complexity of this print, feel free to leave a comment.

This is not meant to be a perfect model, as the trophy itself varied from year to year in its design. The base has also been left blank for the maker to edit as they see fit.

There are 2 versions of both the base and the football. The base has an option for attached holding pegs, and for separate .5" pegs, printable from the files here or of the maker's choice. The football can be printed either solid or hollow, with several sliced options to best fit your printer.
Is great on a key chain and I have had several comments on the one I printed!

title: Bowl Holder (light weight)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
While driving our RV, my Wife brings me snacks(in a bowl). How on earth do you drive and hold a bowl??? So, here is my solution...
I made it to hold light weight snacks like popcorn or chips. I wouldn't suggest using it for anything heavy(i.e. soup). I mounted it on the wall of the RV(next to my drink holder) to the left of the drivers seat.
The bowl that I designed it for is the 8" bowls that come in two packs from Dollar Tree(they always have the same ones available). The bowl snaps into the holder with one hand since I made it with a ramp on the bottom that grabs the lip on the bottom of the bowl. Just un-clip it when you are done.
I wanted it to print in this orientation but was having problems with my printer building accurate support for the latch. therefore the pylon under that latch(remove it after printing). The little waste of ABS it causes was well worth it.

Please let me know if you find this useful(or at least creative).

Keep on creating!

description.text:
This is a case/cover I made for the Elenco FM Radio Kit that you can buy at Barnes and Nobles or Amazon (https://www.amazon.com/Elenco-FM-88K-FM-Radio-Kit/dp/B004YHZE0G/ref=pd_lpo_vtph_21_bs_t_1?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1&refRID=5TAMH1X52TYAX3PYS95S).

After building the radio with my nephews I realized that a case was needed to protect the exposed circuit. The STL files show solid surfaces but I recommend setting your slicer to have no bottom or top layers and set infill pattern to honeycomb to achieve the look in the pictures I have uploaded. This allow the circuit board to still be seen.

The top and bottom pieces should snap into place but if they are too tight or loose, just scale the model in your slicer and try again. The board should fit snuggly in the bottom piece and there are stops on either side to stop it from sliding too far down. Make sure you apply even pressure on the board and don't bend it.

description.text:
I wanted a basic vehicle frame for the Intelligent EV3 Brick, so I decided to print one.
You can either leave this in two pieces, and let the connections to the base hold it secure (this is what I've done for now) or glue the two pieces together and slide the Intelligent brick into place with the battery cover off.
Potential future enhancements:

  • Adding connection holes to the connecting beams would allow it to be more stable without gluing. I'm not sure how well that would print, though.
  • The angled beams coming down are the motor mounts. After connecting the motor, it occurred to me that the motor might be slightly more stable with a "+" hole to match the holes on the motor.
  • It would be nice if the connecting beams had some fluting on the connections instead of being so square.
    Anyhow, print one of each side and connect!

title: UP! MINI spool holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I was using a spool holder that I found on Thingiverse that I wasn't happy with.
The tolerance where it clips onto the rear wall was too loose...'nuf said.

This one fits tightly into the existing hole on the rear of the enclosure and still removes easily if you want.
The length of the spindle allows for any of the spool sizes that I have. I am constantly trying new ABS manufactures to see which I like the best, so I have lots of spool sizes.

I did a light weight version after I had printed the one that I am actually using. I don't think that it is any less structurally sound, it just uses less plastic(I haven't actually printed the lighter version). It seems that everything I design is "A work in progress" as I am always doing modifications.
Now my spool doesn't "walk" to the outside of the spindle causing jams.

If you print it in this orientation with support, you have a little waste but you don't have problems clearing the gap where it grips the enclosure.

Please let me know if you like it and Keep On Creating!

description.text:
TL;DR

WHIRLIGIG is a high-efficiency print-cooling fan duct for the i3 Plus and v2.1. It is my second cooler design, after the GUST.

WHIRLIGIG takes the excess airflow of a blower fan and intentionally vents it to cool the whole active printing area, not just the area underneath the nozzle. This results in less back-pressure, a quieter fan, and more effective 360° cooling, at least on par with the DiiiCooler based on my printing trials (see the photo gallery).

Design goals

WHIRLIGIG meets six design criteria:

  1. Deliver specific cooling as close to the nozzle as possible. This improves the quality of short layers.
  2. Do not trap hot air in the plastic deposition area. Push it away so that warping is reduced.
  3. Vent excess airflow and use it to cool the part, instead of wasting it as back-pressure.
  4. Allow easy access to the nozzle for bed levelling.
  5. Provide a clear line of sight to the nozzle and an unobstructed view of the print-in-progress for filming time lapses (I recommend my super-compact bed-mounted Raspi cam).
  6. Allow easy removal of the entire shroud assembly for access to the hot-end.

Whirligig is a work-in-progress, but it's ready to use right now! I suggest you 'Watch' this thing to get notifications about new revisions.

Important compatibility info

May collide with front-mounted Z braces, so consider using rear braces instead. I use martin_au's Minimalist Z Braces for my i3 Plus. FilamentCorner's Simply Backing Z looks like an analogous kit for the i3 v2.

Known to fit:

  • Wanhao i3 Plus or rebadged versions
    • Stock hot-end/extruder
    • Micro Swiss all-metal hot-end
    • Does not fit Flexion hot-end/extruder (apparently the Flexion nozzle is too short?)
  • Monoprice Maker Select V2.1

This shroud is designed for a Wanhao i3 Plus, or a rebadged version of it. It fits onto an extruder bracket that has M3 holes shaped as slots spaced around 30 mm apart, on a tab that is 45 mm long.

There is a different kind of bracket that has holes (not slots) spaced 40 mm apart, on a tab that is 50 mm long. I have provided a slotted bracket to fit these measurements, but I can't guarantee that the other bracket dimensions are the same or that the shroud will fit your bracket's height.

I have also made the assumption that your nozzle is at least 6 mm tall from the heater block to the tip, which is the case for both the Plus' stock nozzle and also for the Micro Swiss all-metal hot-end's nozzle. WHIRLIGIG cannot fit into the space around a shorter nozzle, and cannot be made to fit there; it's already nearly too thin.

If you are able to use this shroud on a non-Plus model, could you please comment and let the community know? Info about your bracket and nozzle would be good.

Bill of Materials

Note: Always use the latest revision of each STL (e.g. use Rev 2 instead of Rev 1). The newest files are always listed first, and they are always compatible with each other; you can use the Rev 2 duct with the Rev 1 shroud, for example, as long as they are the latest revisions of those objects. The old files remain 'below the fold' in case you want to explore them.

  • 1× Duct.stl. There is also a version with Meshmixer supports included, for those who don't have a slicer that can do custom supports.
  • 1× Bracket.stl. The slotted bracket can fit on brackets with both 30 and 40 mm screw hole distances, and allows you to adjust the shroud along the X axis.
  • (Optional) 10 mm shim.stl to adjust the vertical position of the duct. To make shims of different thicknesses, tell your slicer to scale the shim to a different size along Z only.
  • 1× 50×50×15 mm blower fan. 24 V for Plus machines, 12 V for standard machines.
  • 1× M4 screw (25 mm), washer, and nut.
  • 2× M3 screw (12 mm), washers, and nuts. I bonded wingnuts to grub screws with Loctite, and I use thumb wheels to tighten them down. Tool-less shroud removal!

Installation

  1. Level your bed.
  2. Join the blower fan, Duct, and Bracket using the M4 screw. Leave it loose for now.
  3. Attach Bracket to the fan mounting bracket of the extruder block using the M3 screws. Leave these loose for now. You can place a heat-resistant washer between the heating block and the duct nozzle to insulate it.
  4. Looking from the side, align the nozzle with the opening of the shroud by moving the Bracket forwards or backwards. Tighten the M3 bracket screws.
  5. If needed, add Shims to raise the base of the shroud about 1 mm above the tip of the nozzle.
  6. Zero the Z axis. Pivot the Duct so that it is parallel to the bed. Confirm that it does not collide with the bed.
  7. Tighten the M4 screw.
  8. Suggested cooling profile: 0–20 % speed for the first layer. 100 % for all subsequent layers.

Test print settings

Want to replicate the test prints in the gallery? Here are the settings I used:

  • The test object is DAISY - Print cooling comparison test. I used the settings published on that page:
  • Hobby King PLA
  • 0.40 mm nozzle and 0.20 mm layer height
  • Base speed 100 mm/s
  • Slow down for layers shorter than 1 second
  • 2 perimeters 4 top and bottom layers
  • Outline direction inside-out
  • 0 % internal infill
  • Concentric external infill (it is more difficult than rectilinear because only the outer lines anchor to the walls)

Frequently Asked Questions

Won't it melt from being so close to the nozzle?

Nope! My experience with ducts like this is that so much cold air is passing through them that they barely deform, if at all. I have printed this in PLA and even had it touching the heater block's insulation and it isn't deformed.

If you are worried about the shroud melting while printing a large first layer without the fan running, there are four ways to deal with it:

  1. Trust that PLA has bad thermal conductivity, and the design of the shroud means that only an island on the top surface of the shroud is being heated up, and the heat will find it difficult to spread to the rest of the shroud to cause a structural failure.
  2. Increase the air gap between shroud and block.
  3. Put extra insulation between the shroud and heating block, like a fibre washer.
  4. Run the fan at a very low speed for the first layer (10-20 %) to keep air moving through it. Make sure to actually check that the fan turns at the speed you've selected; my fan won't turn for anything less than 20 % speed.

This was the best way to design the shroud as far as I could see, in order to meet the design requirement of getting right up against the nozzle. The nozzle is only 6 mm tall, so space is limited:

  | Heater block |
  ----------------
1 mm   |     | Insulating air gap
2 mm   |     | ===========
3 mm   |     | Air passage
4 mm   |     | Air passage
5 mm   |     | ===========
6 mm   \_____/ Clearance from print

There's no room, in short, and reducing the air passage just makes the fan louder and makes backflow worse.

What kind of blower fan should I use?

The strongest one you can find with the highest static pressure rating. You can always turn it down if it's too powerful. I've had good times with Shenzhen Gdstime Technology Co. Ltd fans. I've also heard good things about YYQ fans, although I have never used one. But caveat emptor: CFM specs from random sellers are probably untrue.

Can I use a 12 V fan in a 24 V system?

Yes, but you shouldn't. Aside from the possibility of the fans sparking because they're over-volted, they will eventually fail and start making these horrible grinding/rattling sounds.

Notes:

This is a difficult print. There are bridges, there are overhangs. It's entirely possible that you might need to use a different cooler to print this one! My most helpful tip is to avoid putting supports too far inside the duct, because I did design it to print reasonably well supports in the vanes.
The M4 mounting hole in the duct is covered with a thin membrane to make it easier to print. Simply punch through this membrane to open the hole up.

1. GUST was floppy during rapid print movements, had a chance of catching the print. WHIRLIGIG is more rigid.
  2. GUST held the fan at 90°, but the end-play of the rotor on cheap blower fans meant that any XY print movement would make the rotor rattle back and forth, creating a bad and worrying sound. WHIRLIGIG holds the fan upright so that the rotor is unaffected by XY movement.
  3. GUST tried to turn the airflow 90° in a very limited space (I think in a 15×15 mm space!), with a very tight turning radius. WHIRLIGIG has a much larger turning radius.
  4. WHIRLIGIG has a maximum flow amount that is 70% greater than GUST, even without considering the bottom vents.
  5. WHIRLIGIG covers more of the nozzle and more aggressively guides the air through turns in excess of 90°. This means that cooling is more even all around.
  6. WHIRLIGIG includes extra pressure vents on the underside of the duct. They perform a few different tasks:
    • Blower fans can usually deliver more than 100 L/min of air, so the duct is the limiting step in all this. Having extra vents allows excess air pressure be harnessed for cooling, making the fan operate more quietly and creating less wasteful back-pressure.
    • Vents can be used to bleed pressure out of some air rails and not others, so the amount and pressure of air coming out of each rail can be tweaked.
    • Crucially, the bottom vents also cool the parts of the print that are not currently
      underneath the nozzle. I may add more vents later.

26 Jan 2018 (Revision 1)

  • Initial release of WHIRLIGIG.

description.text:
This was just something quick I through together in MasterCam for a friend to play with extrusion, nothing special! This is modeled in inches so this will more than likely need to be scaled up!
I'll update once I give it a print!
Three files for printing a Flying Saucer (UFO).

I have many fond memories of Shel Silversteins's writings, so I wanted to try to make the cover art in 3D.

The largest part of this model is hollow to keep it lightweight. There is a hole in the back to hang it from a nail.

You will need supports for the kids and the dog. NO supports are needed for the base.

There is a place where the sidewalk ends
And before the street begins,
And there the grass grows soft and white,
And there the sun burns crimson bright,
And there the moon-bird rests from his flight
To cool in the peppermint wind.

Let us leave this place where the smoke blows black
And the dark street winds and bends.
Past the pits where the asphalt flowers grow
We shall walk with a walk that is measured and slow,
And watch where the chalk-white arrows go
To the place where the sidewalk ends.

Yes we'll walk with a walk that is measured and slow,
And we'll go where the chalk-white arrows go,
For the children, they mark, and the children, they know
The place where the sidewalk ends.

  • Shel Silverstein

remixed_from.title: Prusa Dual Extruder Dual Fan X Carriage, Fan Duct, Fan Mounts

description.text: This is a dual extruder X carriage adapter for a Prusa. I'm really pleased with how it came out (so far). This is a snap-together design that tightly clamps the hotends and will keep them held very tight so they can't move around while printing. The hotends are then driven by a Bowden extruder configuration. There are four parts to this thing. They all snap together like a puzzle and are then screwed (tightly) onto any standard X carriage. (Try this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:27639) Update (8/2/2012) Added Part B (the large piece that clamps the hotends) with screw holes. This will give a much better grip on the hotends.

Note: Parts A and D are deprecated but included for history's sake. 1] Print two of Part B and one of Part C.
2] Insert the hotends between the two Part B pieces.
3] Use M3 screws with washers on both sides to clamp the two Part B pieces together tightly.
4] Push your filament tubes through from the underside of the larger top piece (after securing M6 nuts to the ends) and ensure that the nuts sit snugly in their homes.
5] Snap the big top piece in place (use pliers as needed).
6] Use screws with washers to really tighten this down onto the X carriage. Don't overdo it, but make sure it is tight enough that it holds it down really firmly.

description.text: Rack to hold the 1911 and P22 upright in a safe.

Here are some legs I designed to allow clearance for my printer to have the proper z-stepper motor clearance when mounting z-axis in center of rails. The design is to help stableize the printer that uses 20x20 extrusion for the frame. The boxes friction fit to the leg allowing the 20x20 to seat in it. These are a must if you have a kit that came as mine did with poor designed parts that don't fit correctly. Not only do they allow clearance they also allow for manual bed leveling which was next to impossible with mine as it came with wing nuts for the bed and sat 1.5 inches from the table.

Print these at 220c hotend, 60c bed 0.3 layer height if you are in a hurry 0.1 if you want quality.

title: Protective box for 1 (one) inch neodymium magnetic cube (TPU recommended)

description.text:
Magnets are cool.
Makers are cool.
Two great things that go great together.
Like chocolate and peanut butter.
Unless you're allergic to peanuts, in which case... not so much.

Anyway, one inch neodymium cube magnets are very cool but due to their powerful nature they have a tendency to fly out of your hands and slam against the nearest metal object. Hopefully your fingers are clear when this happens.

This little thing is a protector that your slip your one-inch cube magnet into and it... well... protects it.

There are two versions: one with solid walls and one with little square cutouts that allow you to more easily extract the magnet (however, it is fairly easy to get the magnet out of either by simply sticking the open face of the magnet (gently) against a metal object).

Anyway, the idea is really to print this in TPU to give the magnet a cushion and then to place the magnet inside and glue the cover onto the protector. The protector only affects the strength of the magnet slightly (assuming your magnet is a good strong neodymium magnet), so (IMHO) there is no reason IMHO you'd want to remove it anyway.

The cutout version looks cooler, but does not afford as much protection.

The other plus side of the full cover one is that if the magnet breaks (and yeah, it still can break if you let it slam hard enough) the full cover protector will keep the magnet in cubic shape...though I do not know how well the magnet will work if you crack it inside the protector. I mean, this is obviously what we are trying to avoid, right?

Anyway, you could probably use PLA, PETG or ABS, but the protection would be lessened because those are more likely to shatter due to their rigidity...and that could be a danger in and of itself...so I strongly recommend TPU.

This is very easy to print and almost any decent settings will do. Best to experiment and see what you think offers the best protection based on your filament characteristics.

With that said, I would suggest (beyond recommending TPU) that you use at least a 0.8mm shell and perhaps 20 to 50 percent infill to create a small air pocket/cushion. However, this protector is not really that thick, so even 100 filled TPU might work better since the air pocket is not nearly as important (IMHO) as having a good strong wall around the magnet.

Anyway, enjoy it and please remember that powerful magnets should always to be treated with respect... I mean, a magnet can still knock you up, even when it's wearing protection. (I learned that in health class).

description.text:
This is another take on filament swatches. This allows keeping track of colors and types on hand and ease color choice for your next project.

The core of this system is a rolodex size swatch that is printed out for each filament/color. It features a spot for an address size label to record manufacturer, color name, temps, and a purchase date (useful if you want to repurchase the same color years later). The swatch also features a gradual incline area which, when sliced, will generate septs each a layer higher.

To help organize swatches, tab dividers are available to sort swatches by material, color, manufacturer, or anything else. A set of blank set of tabs are included for use for a label maker and the Fusion 360 file is included if you want to create your own tabs with raised lettering (as seen here).

Finally, a 2 part box is included for storage of swatches.

The original Fusion 360 file is included for your editing pleasure. Check the Change Parameters section under Modify as most dimensions are tied to User Created Parameters for easy editing and parametric use.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15 mm

Infill:

Doesn't Matter

Notes:

Infill percentage doesn't matter too much as there are little amounts of infill at play. Going sparse, such as 10%, will suffice. All items can print without supports.

If the STL import too small in your choice of slicer software, scale the parts uniformly by 2540%. This is a byproduct of Fusion 360 creating the STL in 1 inch = 1 unit (it was designed in inches) and your slicer treating it as 1 unit = 1 mm.

Tabs and Filament swatches come off the build plate ready to go with nothing more than cleaning the edges if needed. The box prints in two parts and the hinges snap together. While the design to snap fit, the pins on the bottom portion may need to be filed down a bit for a better fit, especially with the sets in the middle.

If desired, add your label to the the swatches as they come off the printer.

title: Realistic DX-350 Shortwave Radio Battery Door
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I've had this DX-350 radio forever, and I've never had a battery door for it, until now!

If you're reading this, you may be the only other person on earth that still has a DX-350.

I went through 12 versions until I had one that fit tight, went on and off easily, and didn't interfere with anything under the door. I have no idea what the original looked like, or how it worked, so this could be better or worse. No idea. If yours is also missing altogether, this one is definitely better :)

Post-printing break off the small support at the end of the door clip. It's only .4mm wide and easily pops right off.

To install the door, slip the hinge end in first, then pull the door back with the finger slot to allow the tongue to fit into the slot. I used plain old PLA, and it was plenty flexible. I've had it on and off 10x without issue.

Enjoy!

Elna bobbin for classic Elna sewing machines. Our machine came with one metal bobbin that was approximately 21 x 11 mm. This bobbin is 20.1 x 10.8 mm although you can adjust it using OpenSCAD or the Customizer (if it's working). I recommend using this slightly smaller size in a 1970s Elna machine as the plastic is not as slippery as metal.

This is a two part design. It is a tight fit and hard to get apart once together. I do recommend applying a dab or two of super glue on the inside of the bigger piece. Then push together the two halves (it may take a little bit of force and you need to align them just right). After the bobbin is together, wipe the inside bore to ensure no glue remains (there is a small empty space that should trap most/all of a small amount of excess).

remixed_from.title: AM8 - Metal Frame for Anet A8

description.text:
Hey guys! On my second and third AM8 builds I find myself not needing to use the frame's feet. Instead I set the frame directly onto a foam mat. The problem is that the stock LCD mount sits below the frame. Without the feet the frame will rest on the LCD cover. These mounts raise up the LCD allowing it to clear the table and brings it forward a little bit clearing the adjustment screw for the Y axis belt.

NOTE: There is a trade off with this mount. It does make the Y axis adjustment screw difficult to access. However since i very rarely need to tighten them it's a non issue for me...

IMPORTANT!!! You will need to mirror this in your slicer in order to have the left side mount.

description.text: Here is a simple but effective wall mount spool holder for a standard 1kg spool. Use 2 screws to attach it to the wall, standard screws should be able to have the heads recessed into the bracket easily. Use an m5 bolt to attach the cap (65mm diameter) to the main mount piece to hold the spool on, it should thread in relatively easily. For reference the diameter of the semi circle is 51mm and from the end of it to the flat part of the bracket is 70mm so it should accommodate most spools. The stl file "wall mount spool holder" will have to be rotated in your slicing software prior to printing, you can have the large bottom of it flat on the bed or sticking up in the air. For me it printed well with the flat side that will go against the wall, flat on the bed as shown in one of the pictures.

author: silkfpv

title: Leveling/measuring/comparing tool for 3D printer or other uses

description.text:
I needed a way to compare one side of the z-axis level to the other side on my 3D printer as it droops when the steppers are powered off. I ordered parts to link the z-axis lead screws together however in the meantime, this tool makes it easier to compare the two sides.

Marked "work in progress" because the bolt might need to be slightly smaller by about 0.1-0.2mm or I printed the base with too much fill. Print with no more than 50% fill. For too tight screw, put some chapstick or other lubricant on the threads and work the bolt in and out. The problem might also be that one side of the bolt thread is exposed so it distorts the threads on that side relative to the non-exposed parts. Tricky!

I used the a threads library that is technically very good however it looks like my $fn value was too high thus producing a very large STL file. It also takes a very long time to render in OpenSCAD.

title: Bobbin For Spinning Wheel With 110mm Length, 6.75mm rod like Ashford Kiwi 2

description.text:
So I'm making a eSpinner but along the way I wanted to test my Bobbin design. The idea here is that I would make different end caps to have a very good fit on each shaft size. The first one I'm uploading is a 6.75mm shaft size that works with an Ashford Kiwi spinning wheel.
So print 2 of the adapters, one for each end and then just one of each of the other parts.
You do need to glue one side of the bobbin on after printing as that was just easiest for me, the end caps that can adapt the shaft size seem to stay in ok on their own.
There's a chance if you don't do a super job gluing it that you get a tiny wiggle, but in our case it wasn't enough to cause issues as the whirl on this spinning wheel has a more obvious wiggle.

author: mussy

title: "Crocodile" belt tensioner for MaXYposi
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a belt tensioner for the diy cnc-machine "MaXYposi". I can be used to replace the two aluminium tension blocks of the x-axis. It will fit the standard x-axis - so no extra holes are needed.
The tensioner for the y-axis is available in two different design (2- or 3-holes for fixation).

Update:
14 Feb 2018:
Uploaded x-axis tensioner v2 with "through" holes for tensioner screw and nail.
Uploaded y-axis V1 Revision1 - Tensioner with modified mounting holes.

Bill of materials
  • 1 printed 3d part
  • 3 nails (3,8 x 80 mm) two for x-axis, one for y-axis
  • 2 M4 nut, one for each axis
  • 2 M4 x 50 screw , one for each axis
  • 2 M4 x 40 screws (flat head) for fixing the tensioner onto the x-axis sleigh
  • 2 or 3 screws 3,8 x 50mm, round head, for fixing the y-axis tension on the wooden base

Print out the 3D file (0,3mm slices and 20 - 25 percent infill should do it)
Bend about 25mm ot each nail in a 90 degrees angle.
Cut one nail to fit the side length of 20mm x 30mm.
Cut the other nail to fit the side length of 20mm x 20mm.
Place the in the slot (of the 3D part) adjacent to the end with two 4mm holes.
Put the screw in the upper hole (closest to the slot) and screw it through the nut.
Insert the longer nail part from inside the slot (through the lower 4mm hole).
The other nail goes to the other side of the slot (where the inner 4mm hole is).
Bend the ends of the belt to tight loops and insert them from each side into the slot.
The nail ends must fit into the loops. Now you can adjust the tension of the belt by turning the screw.

The tensioner for the y-axis is more or less a half of the x-axis and is assembled accordingly.

description.text:
Change gears for the Craftsman Model 109 Lathe.
This should be the complete set, with the following gears:

32T, 36T, 40T, 44T, 46T, 52T, 54T, 56T

The fit of the keyways and axles may ned to be sanded just a bit to get them to fit correctly, but these areas should be as tight as possible to ensure accurate threading, so I kept them tight.

I've printed the 44 tooth, and 32 tooth gears, and the they mesh perfectly with their cast metal counterparts. I can't attest to how long they will last under use, but they feel very sturdy. I recommend printing with high quality ABS, or something like PETG for durability.

Let me know how they work! I haven't had a chance to try them yet as I'm still restoring my Model 109 lathe.

Feedback greatly appreciated, thanks!

author: DB3JHF

description.text:
This remake of "Game Genius Simon says game" by CircuitoMaker (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1990861) includes a display to show how many buttons have been pressed in the correct sequence. This feature provides important feedback to the player, so they can see if their memory is improving.

...............................
Hardware
...............................
I designed a custom PC board (Eagle files included) to hold a 2 digit display, MAX7219 Matrix driver IC, an Arduino Mini Pro, a buzzer and some headers to wire the switches & leds. The MAX7219, Arduino and some passive SMD components are mounted on the back of the board. The Display and Buzzer are mounted on the front of the board. I made my board using the toner method.

I drilled holes in the case for the 2-Digit Common Cathode 0.56" display and a DC power socket. The Power socket is wired so that when a DC supply is inserted, the 9V battery is disconnected.

To have make everything fit, I designed a new bottom that is ribbed so that only one screw is required to lock the bottom in place. I also extended the block that the screw is inserted into. The ones in the original base design are very weak and break easily.

...............................
Software
...............................
For the sound, I used the software I wrote for the Arduino Piano (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2665714). It contains more features than what is required but it does allow you to change the notes and the tunes it plays. (Sketch included)

I needed a clamp to repair a bicycle bell. So this is the result.
You can configure pretty much anything. Length, diameter, number of holes, hole distance etc.
Use it in your script (parametric) or try the thingiverse customizer.

This is a quick 6-inch cable hanger that I designed to fit up inside the braces under Rubbermaid, Plano and Sterilite plastic shelving found at most big box stores in the USA. I turned one of these shelves into an electronics charging station to help organize my office.

With 3 drones, 3 DSLR cameras, 5 GoPros, 2 Canon Vixia Camcorders, 5 USB Battery Packs, LED Panel Batteries, etc, I needed a place to not only store all of the batteries on, but a flat surface to organize chargers and charging cables.

This is my solution to preventing a bunch of cables laying tangled on the shelf. I used Zip-Ties to secure this under the top shelf, drilling matching holes in the ribbing that was molded into the shelf.

author: rohiteshbhan

description.text: This is a battery tray liner for a radio controlled car. It has a flat bottom and a honeycomb support structure to hold the battery firmly, yet allow some compliance. It is designed to be printed with TPE, or another flexible filament.

The idea came to me when I was in my mid-twenties. My mid-1920s, that is. I walked into a Jazz club in Manhattan called the Frizzy Willow--you know the place: down on 59th and 2nd--and I ordered myself a cocktail. Yeah, it was prohibition, but nobody could touch me. I was on top of the world. Sinatra was playing. Of course he was. New York wasn't his home town, but it was his favorite town. That's how it seemed when he played his music there anyway.

As I picked up my cocktail, I gave a slight nod to the chief of police who was drinking a beer at the end of the table with the Mayor, and I removed my hat. He nodded back and I went to my usual table to enjoy the music and smoke a fine Cuban cigar. I was surprised to find a woman sitting in my seat. I was taken aback. 'This woman is going to be my wife one day', I thought without any hesitation. Wow. I didn't even know her name and I already knew this to be true.

We wed on a Sunday. It was a gray, but pleasant Fall evening just six months after we met. I still didn't know her name, but she knew mine. Soon, we would have five children: Gertrude, Moe, Sally, John, and Alfred. They were good kids. John, was a fighter. Not in the sense that he used violence or anger--nay, he fought hard to live his life. He never was a healthy child: Tuberculosis, Malaria, and Measles kept him down as a young child. But he soon grew out of it to become sort of a leader of his siblings. They all worshiped him, although they never really let him know it.

We return to the bar scene to find me still standing there, unable to speak at the mere sight of my future wife. Normally, I am quick-witted and find that the right words are always there for me. I shook my head a bit to clear it out, and I asked her what her name was. She didn't say. She just said, "would you mind sitting here with me? I could use the company.". We didn't speak for the rest of the evening. We merely enjoyed each other's company, as well as the music. We both had a few more drinks before finding ourselves back on Manhattan's streets, eager to share the next day together.

The next morning, when I woke up, this design was all I could think about.

Sadly, I never did see her again. I wonder what happened to her? Did she ever wed? Did I ever truly meet her, or was she merely a dream? So many questions. So little time.

Over here at ¯_(ツ)_/¯ Squadron we printed a Nebulon B Frigate, funded by anonymous investments from clandestine accounts in offworld exchange stations in the Unknown Regions, but just as production got going the ship snapped in half along the spine during a construction accident that resulted in the frigate meeting the shop floor at high velocity. Some of the workers involved are known Imperial sympathizers and one has been convicted for the sale of glitterstim. Rebel command assures loyalists that the workers at fault will be punished, though the servo-welders' union remains a powerful political force in the south-southeast extension base on Yavin and looks to flex its bureaucratic muscle in the ensuing litigation.

In view of these circumstances, the medium freighter mechanic division designed this clamp to connect the spine sections of the Nebulon B and hopefully provide some kind of extra hull reinforcement. Who is designing these capital ships that they are so easily destroyed anyway? Mining is a dirty, destructive process, and even a cursory glance at the geoplanetary-stats in mining guild archives demonstrates that we are depleting our galaxy's natural resources at an alarming rate. Don't get me wrong, both my brothers and my father fought in the Rebel Alliance, and my grandfather knew Bail Organa's cousin. But sometimes it's like the Rebel Alliance and the Galactic Empire are locked in perpetual conflict on purpose, making us more docile in the process. It was foretold in the prophecy of Angladon that when the stars surrounding the nebulae of Orisnizoe-4 reach their maximum fiscious altitude relative to the second planet of the Quad-nair system, a conquerer-people from Beyond The Not-Yet-Known-West will rise from the fire-caves of Smilindion and subdue the Haplaster Regency. The evidence is clear, so I won't state the obvious; instead, I'll just tell you to keep in mind the implications of this for the fate of hyperspace travel beyond the Tingel Arm. You might not agree with me and that's OK, but I hope you can at least see where I am coming from.

Once we get our check from an anonymous source via sketchy means we will continue production and get this clamp on this ship to get this war bird in in the sky.

May the force be with you.

description.text:
A tape holder for tapes size from 120mm to 80mm. Design to be wall mounted. You need two printed pieces and 2 booms (12mm or 12.8mm/half inch for you imperial guys). I've used one meter booms and they bend little bit in the middle, so its just about max for booms this size. For longer booms use at least 3 brackets.

You may need some file action since the booms are usually over sized. If the booms are to loose use some CA glue. Holes for the screws are 5.5mm, so use 5mm screws.

I've printed mine in PETG with 30% infill, but PLA will also be fine.

title: Solder paste dispenser for less then $5

description.text:
Solder paste dispenser.

Its a try to create a solder paste dispenser using cheap components from aliexpress. I've got my inspiration from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:384680 and design it from a scratch. The biggest improvement is the plunger system.

You'll need:

  • arduino pro mini ($1.5 delivered)
  • stepper motor with a driver board 28BYJ-48 ($1.74 delivered)
  • 5mm to 5mm coupler (1$ delivered)
  • M5 nut
  • M5 threaded rod 73mm long
  • power jack
  • tactile button
  • wires
  • some self tapping screws

You'll need a serial adapter to program arduino.

Notes

  • connect the coupler so that threaded rod will push against the shaft of the motor;
  • if You have to, adjust the plunger scale so it will go in to the housing without any drag;
  • since the uln2003 have almost 2V dropout, use at least 7V power adapter to power the motor. I use mine with 9V, but works also with 12V;
  • I've design it for a working length, so I can put new paste in and extrude all of it. Should work with any solder paste, but I use it with aliexpress MECHANIC XG-Z40 ($3.5 each)
  • do some failing on the plunger and the socket, so its smooth;
  • wiring you can figure out from pictures and arduino sketch
  • glue the m5 nut in the plunger, so it wont come out during retraction. If the socket is to tight, heat up the nut.

Some throwbacks:

  • its uncomfortable to hold. The motor is mounted far of where you hold it, so its unbalanced.
  • if there is a lot of solder inside syringe, then the pressure builds up and need much more retraction so solder wont drip out after releasing the button

To improve

  • change the coupler, so the whole body would be shorter, possibly some elastic hose would work fine
  • shorten to body, and move motor closer
  • maybe change the design so it would be half the travel, and after dispensing half the paste , take the paste out and place an extender for the plunger. That way the body could also be shorter.
  • add a potentiometer to change the speed/retraction length.
  • design custom PCB
  • adjust screw hole size and depth, all holes for PCB mounting.
  • software could use some improvement

In the end it improved the work to apply the solder for project for which I don't have a stencil.

Designed using Fusion 360 http://a360.co/2A1AaFL

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30-50%

Notes:

I've designed the body so it will print without support.

I used PLA to print.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9qgwJqB8lFm

This is a paste extruder made for 50ml luer lock syringes. http://www.mdpi.com/2227-7080/5/3/50

Hardware:
1x 50ml luer lock syringe (31mm OD, 29mm ID) + blunt tip luer needles

1x Nema17 motor
2x 608 bearings 8x22x7
1x M8 threaded rod 150mm long
1x M8 nut
4x M4x40 screws + nuts
2x M3x16 screws + nuts

4x M4 screws for mounting

Cut syringe plunger off and glue 3D printed part to it, then thread the M8 rod through it. M8 nut fits in the bigger gear, and is sandwiched between the spacers (2mm one on top) and the bearings. Use light grease on the screw/nut mechanism.

STEP file is available if you need to change/design a mount that fits your printer.

title: Heavy Flamer Terminator Warhammer 40.000
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: A Heavy Flamer is a larger, more powerful version of the standard Flamer, capable of projecting hotter and denser flames. This means that Heavy Flamers possess better armour-piercing capabilities than standard Flamers. In the Imperial Guard, Heavy Flamers are often used by specialists in dense conditions, such as jungle warfare, urban warfare and close-quarters melee combat. It is, however, most commonly found mounted on vehicles, though it is just reasonable enough in size to be carried by a team of two human troopers or a single Space Marine. Any lack of accuracy is more than offset by the wide gouts of burning Promethium it fires that are almost impossible to dodge. Heavy Flamers must be fuelled by backpack fuel canisters -- a considerable weight is already part of the weapon profile and as such the canister must be worn on the back of one of the two normal wielders if they are unaugmented humans. Despite their cumbersome weight, these formidable weapons are a valuable addition to Space Marine Devastator Squads and Terminator-armoured veterans, who utilise them for clearing Space Hulks of any potential threats, or to provide a bulwark of defence against encroaching enemy forces. As such, Heavy Flamers are a favoured weapon of Deathwatch Terminators wherever the Tyranid threat swarms.

print_settings.Notes:: Use a raft or brimm for this, some printers can handle it without those, but just to be on a safer side, use them.

description.text:
Wanted to add some LEDs to my tank and since i had a headlight system from Turnigy still laying around, i thought they would look pretty good on it.

But the main problem here was, that they had no mount included, so either i drill 22mm wide holes into the front bumper (wich would be very difficult) or design a mount.

I designed a few versions and decided to use this design.

You can get the headlight system at online stores like hobbyking, ebay or amazon.
They are also come from other brands, but the housing must have 22mm so they fit in.

https://hobbyking.com/en_us/turnigy-high-power-headlight-system.html

Printer:

Hephestos 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2mm

Infill:

20-25%

Notes:

Use a raft or brimm for this, some printers can handle it without those, but just to be on a safer side, use them.

How to assemble this

What you need:

Superglue medium viscosity and activator spray
light sanding paper 140-180grid
4x M3x20mm screws
4x M3 nuts or lock-nuts
4x M3 washers (optional)
Powertool and a 3mm drill

After you got everything printed, take the back part (big one with the holder) and place it on a flat surface.
Sand the surface of the black housing of the LED spots a little so the glue holds better.
Press the LED spot in it and then add superglue to each of the 3 holes, do one at a time, each with activator spray to speed up the hardening.

After that, take the front part (small shade) and mount it also with superglue, no activator needed for this. You don´t need to install it, but it looks better.

After that, take the base parts and add the m3 nuts.
They are press-fit, so no need for glue or heating up the nut.

Now take the sanding paper and sand the left and right side of the bar from the back part a little, so it fits better into the base holders. This step is optional and deppends on your printer quality. If the bar fits into the base without sanding, then don´t do it.

Line everything up so the M3x20mm screws fit right in.
No need for drilling with a 3mm drill, just screw it in.
If you want, add a little screwlock liquid into it or use lock-nuts.

All you need to do now: Look where you want to mount them and mark the holes for a 3mm drill. You can also glue them in place, but i recommend screwing.

Since i primary wanted to mount them on the front bumper of the rc speed tank, this is a easy step and needs no explanation. Just watch that you don´t place them in a spot where are screw is under it. Here you can use the M3 washers for the base mount and under the front bumper.

Printed Parts and Turnigy headlight system Press the spots in it and look that the cables line up with the lower bar Sand each sides of the bar a little with 140 or 180grid sandpaper if the don´t fit into the base holder. Add the nuts, get the screws trough and you are finished.

author: vladker

title: Extreme Overhang Test
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is an overhang test that go from 30° to 90° from vertical axis.

This item was used to help evaluate cooling performance during the development of the DiiiCooler and CiiiCooler to see how they performed in different directions.

[Settings]

  • Remember, you want these prints to fail(!) consistently, default slicing settings are usually meant to get prints not to fail, which is why they are not good for these tests. (Especially layer times)
  • Be sure to keep your layer times as short as possible and your temperatures at high settings so that with your baseline cooler, the cooling starts failing at ~60-70° overhang with your settings.
  • Use 0.2 mm layer height (Preferably).

[Directions - Baseline]

  • Mount the cooler you wish to use as your baseline in your tests, find the correct combination of temperatures, speeds and layer time according to above [Settings]
  • Slice the item in default position (0°), print it and mark the direction the item was pointing towards the front of the printer with a permanent marker, and write underneath on the flat surface what cooler was used (and settings?).
  • Slice the item again rotated 45° to the left or right, and then print and repeat until you have done so with 8 prints in total (one for each direction).

[Directions - Comparison]

  • Mount the cooler you wish to compare the results for, but "DO NOT CHANGE THE SLICING SETTINGS FROM WHAT WAS USED IN BASELINE"! (Remember, settings should be consistent so that the only difference is the actual cooler used!)
  • Just repeat the above procedure until you got the 8 pieces printed with the new cooler.
  • Flip the items around and you should now be able to have a great comparison while developing your cooler or finding out how good others are.

author: nmaggioni

description.text:
Extracted human tooth, scanned using X-ray microtomography at 15 microns. The mesh's vertices was reduced by a magnitude of 10, in order to upload.

This work was carried out for results for a PhD, looking into teaching anatomy through simulation based medical education. We actively encourage the use of our models, and we love to hear back from you if you use it in your research or education purposes. If you do use our work, we would kindly ask you to reference this piece of work, by using the following reference;

Cresswell-Boyes, A. J. (2018). Extracted Mandibular First Molar - XMT Produced Model.

Any questions regarding data collection, or model manipulation, please do not hesitate to ask.

comments.text:
Hi, good work!
What format does the machine generate and how did you convert to get this?
comments.author: ShuttleSpace

comments.text:
Hi there,
Thank you. The X-ray scanner, produces .tom (tomography) files once reconstructed, these are then converted to .nc files for the volumetric data, then the external and internal meshes are exported as a .ply file.

description.text:
This is a remix of the bed stabilizers created by xyzaxis. I printed and installed those and was really happy with how well they worked. I found that trying to install the two piece units was a bit challenging, so I remixed this and created a clip that is one piece.

These fit my Wanhao i3 Plus perfectly. They are a bit snug but will push into the right spot with a little pressure. Once they are on the bed, then install the screws and springs as normal. The clip stabilizes the spring, and also offers a bit of extra pressure which can be useful if you have a loose corner.

Yes, you can print this with PLA. It does not touched the heated portion of the bed. These have been tested and are installed on my printer.

author: Nazarrush1

title: DistoX v1 holder for Leica Disto A3

description.text:
This is a DistoX v1 holder. It can hold a Leica Disto A3 for calibrating its DistoX upgrade in combination with Mykyta Kozlov's calibration cube as announced on FB: https://www.facebook.com/groups/2205123638/permalink/10153870390228639/ and described here: https://bitbucket.org/ngry/distox2_cube/overview

(for non-initiated cavers, a DistoX is an upgrade for a Leica Disto designed by Beat Heeb to be used for surveying caves. You can find Beat's site about paperless cave surveying here: https://paperless.bheeb.ch/ )

Mykyta's setup is designed for the DistoX version 2 based on the newer Leica Disto X310, but a lot of speleologists I'm still using the older model which is still working fine! So I tried out some designs and this is my final one which I'm actually using.

I'm not a script-oriented open-SCAD expert, so I just designed the holder in FreeCAD and exported it as stl-file so DistoX model 1 owners can download it to mount their device if they build the DistoX calibrator as described by Mykyta.

It has an optional side hole for mounting a non-magnetic screw, but you don't really need it, as the Disto fits very well without falling out even when upside-down.
The rotation axis' position is optimized for the Disto A3 turning around its laser beam's centre.
A slit in the right hand side permits sliding in the Disto without removing the wrist strap.
The hollow tubular shaft on the bottom has the square end fitting into Mykyta's calibration cube but you need to slide in the 8mm aluminum rod as mentioned in his design.

Tip: I printed Mykyta Kozlov's cube and my DistoX-1's holder in fluorescent PLA glowing in the dark, so collegues see your installation before walking over it !

As usual: dont' forget to use only non-magnetic parts and be sure your tripod is, too. Good luck and happy cave surveying !!

Prusa

Prusa Clone

remixed_from.title: Nerf barrel to 1/2 inch pvc pipe adapter

description.text:
This is an adapter that will allow you to attach a 1.5 inch schedule 40 PVC pipe to a nerf gun. It should work with the Star Wars Jyn Erso Nerf blaster as well as the Cassian Andor sniper blaster.

There are three variations. One has a flange for the pipe to rest on. The other two do not have this flange nor the flange on the front (so they can be printed front-side down). One of the later 2 has meshmixer supports for the inner lugs. All three will accept a piece of 1/2 inch PVC on the inner hole making this a dual purpose adaptor.
Basic litho of my favorite band. I love these pictures. Salford boys.

I landed hard on the ground last fall and snapped off one of the landing gear. I tried to glue it back on but it only took a little harder then normal landing to snap it off. I found the landing gear by Pink_Iguanas but could not figure a good way to glue it on. I made a snap on piece for the cross beam and then added the flat top at the exact height to make the drone level. I printed them as one piece but found that the support messes with the ability to snap on. So i split the 2 and glued them together after printing.   
UPDATE This WILL work with 2.0 as well. I have verified this.  
DISCLAIMER Please note: I made the clip to be very tight. If you want to take it off do so with care. If you force it you may damage the cross beam and i have not seen a 3D printable version of the cross beams.

Print part 1 with no support and the opening facing straight up.
Print part 2 with support with the top up. This will give you a flat surface to glue.

remixed_from.author: twuelfing
remixed_from.title: SpaceX Falcon 9 Commemorative First Landing Model 1:60ish

title: SpaceX Falcon 9 first landed orbital booster 1/87 scale (H0)

description.text:
This a 1/87 scale model of the first landed orbital booster from SpaceX which landed on 21. december 2015.

I was amazed by Twuelfing's model and how good it looked in his display so I decided to build it, too. I have many small cars in scale 1/87 (H0) so I decided to print it in this much smaller scale. Because I wasn't able to print all the details of the original model in my scale I decided to remix it and remodel the things that had to be modified for printing in 1/87. Twuelfing, I thank you very much for this awesome model, I am amazed of the work you put into it.

I only uploaded my new parts. For the Octaweb (engines) and legs you can use the files provided by twuelfing and scale them in your slicer-software by 65.92%.

EDIT: I was asked to upload all the files, so now there are parts, labeld "_scaled". These are twuelfings parts, scaled by 65.92%, so you can print them directly in 1/87-scale.

I'm not quite sure about the length of the interstage. I think the original interstage is that of F9 v1.1 (block 2). Flight 20 (first landing) was the maiden flight of F9 v1.2 full thrust (block 3) where the interstage was longer.

In 1/87-scale the interstage is now around 1cm longer than before.

https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Falcon_9_Full_Thrust&oldid=820766059

https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_Falcon_9_and_Falcon_Heavy_launches&oldid=822382284

I remodeled the aluminum grid fins of F9 flight 20 because I wasn't able to print them on my FDM-printer in my scale.

The remodeled ones have a grid-width of exactly one extruded line when printing on a 0.4mm nozzle.

I printed the hydraulic cylinders that move the landing legs instead of making them from metal. It's a bit more fragile but because of the smaller scale of 1/87 it works, as long as you don't push hard against the rocket.

The 2mm and 3mm parts were printed lying and sanded afterwards to get them round.

I addeed a tool to glue the single parts together coaxially. Simply lay the parts onto the tool and push together the single pieces using glue between them.

For the rocket body I used a piece of PVC-pipe used to fix cables under the ceiling. The diameter is 40mm what fits 1/87 quite nicely.

https://www.bauhaus.info/kabelschutzrohre/stangenrohr/p/22828668

adapteroctaweb is the thing you can glue into the pipe to attatch interstage and octaweb.

description.text:
I wanted a tray to hold my 9XR-Pro steady but didn't want one that wouldn't allow me to fly thumb style so I came up with this design which gives me the best of both worlds without costing a fortune.

Requires 2x M6x30mm bolt/screws, 2x M6 nuts, 2x M6 washers and 2x M3x15mm bolt/screws.

Thread the M3 bolts into the thumb screws and secure with some CA glue.
The frame can then be bolted to the back of the radio by using the existing bolt holes in the back of the radio.
The add the front plate insert which holds the edges of the radio's "feet" to keep the front stable. This just needs to hold things steady so not too tight but once in place a drop of glue on the tabs will keep it solid.

The arms can then be attached by threading the M6 bolt and washer through the arm, inserting the M6 nut into the cutout and screwing them in from the outside in. Don't go too tight until you have tested the fit - it needs to hold on but not be fully tight.
Try the radio on for size and adjust the angles of the arms to suit your own preference. Once you're happy with the angle, add a drop of glue to the arm to tray join and tighten the bolts down fully.

I used a double ended neck strap from a holdall bag for this but any strap with two clip ends will work.

Wall mounted headset holder adorned with PUBG logos.

This is a support I designed to hold your Dremel rotatory tool in an upward vertical direction and used it in this position. Is made out of two pieces, a flat base in the rear and the tool holder, there are two versions of this holder, one uses the standard cap that comes with your typical Dremel tool, and the other uses the cap that comes with the Detailer's Grip Attachment 577 (The one in the pictures, if you don't own it, I can't recommend it enough, its super useful). You only need one!

The base can be nailed or screwed to a table, but I recommend use a cramp and don't drill your workstation. The two pieces can be held with a screw, or glue together. You can also print both pieces as one, but that will need a lot of support.

I have plans to add a little work table to hold pieces in complete horizontal, that what the pill-shaped holes are for, or design a longer and bigger custom cap, but so far it works like it supposes to. Hope you find it useful.

title: M36 Plasma Cannon Terminator Warhammer 40.000
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Plasma Cannon, also sometimes called the Heavy Plasma Gun, is an Imperial heavy weapon that relies on plasma technology to deliver lethal blasts of superheated matter to the target. Plasma Weapons work by using hydrogen fuel suspended in a cryogenic state, in either fuel flasks or backpack containers. As the fuel is fed into the miniature fusion core inside the weapon, the hydrogen energises into plasma which is held in the core of the weapon by powerful electromagnetic containment fields. When fired, the fields dilate open and the plasma is ejected via a linear magnetic accelerator as a bolt of superheated matter akin to a solar flare in appearance and temperature. This bolt will explode on impact and can generate the destructive heat of a small sun. For this reason, Plasma Weapons are sometimes called “Sun Guns” by the common Imperial population.

       Heavily utilised by the Dark Angels Space Marine Chapter, the Plasma Cannon uses replaceable charges rather than a carried power-supply. This makes the weapon lighter, allowing for other gear to be carried, but reduces the overall number of shots possible.

remixed_from.author: tjb1
remixed_from.title: Legacy Kossel Groove Mount Hotend Bowden Adapter 1.75mm

title: Probeless Auto Level Hotend Mount for E3D and Kossel Deltabot

description.text:
v.2 files at: https://github.com/Democratek/Probeless-Auto-Level-Hotend-Mount-for-E3D-and-Kossel-Deltabot-v.2
Probeless autolevel based on touch-probe digitizer. This includes a cap that meshes a 5mm pressure fitting for a bowden tube to a E3D hotend, a retaining clip that secures the hotend in the cap, and an effector with holes positioned to allow bolts from the hotend mount to pass through the effector. Springs at the bottom of the bolts, below the effector, hold the hotend mound against the contacts, yet allow the mount to be pushed up to open the contacts when the hotend bumps the bed during the autolevel procedure. Effector is a derivative of the original Kossel effector (https://github.com/jcrocholl/kossel/). See it in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=afdJ4ZaCnrA

Materials:
3x 20mm M2 bolts
1 ball point pen spring
6 brass tacks
3 brass screws
thin wire (cat 5 strands)
soldering iron
Printed parts
Print out the effector, hotend cap, and retaining clip, and the first few layers of an extra retaining clip.
Clean out the inside of the cap with a razor/chisel & sandpaper so that the hotend fits snugly. Insert the top of the hotend through the hole in the effector and secure the hotend cap to the hotend.
Clean out the inside of the retaining clip so that it fits snugly around the constriction below the top of hotend.
Line up the 3 holes on the hotend cap with the 3 holes on the retaining clip.
Drill out the 3 holes in the hotend cap and retaining clip so that the M2 bolts thread snugly through both.
Keep turning the M2 bolts so that they thread through the hotend cap, through the retaining clip, and through the holes in the effector.
Cut the ball point pen spring into 3 peices.
Put the thin retaining clip section around the hotend, below the effector, on top of the highest heatsink fin.
As you screw the 3 bolts down past the effector to meet the second (thin) retaining clip, slip the springs over the tips of the bolts, compressing them between the effector and the retaining clip. Continue to screw the bolts until they screw slightly into the holes in the thin retaining clip.
The hotend cap and clip should now be held snug against the top of the effector by the springs.
Drill some thin pilot holes or use a heated pin to bore pairs of holes in the effector midway between the M2 bolts. These pairs of holes should be spaced about the thickness of the brass screws that will act as the upper contacts. The tacks will be inserted into these holes in the effector and act as the lower contacts.
Cut 2 short lengths of wire that are a little longer than necessary to join the sets of contacts, and strip the ends. Form little circles at both ends of the wire so that the tacks can be inserted through these holes and solder at the mid point of the tacks. You should end up with a short wire with tacks soldered onto each end.
Hold a wired tack with tweezers and position over the pilot hole in the effector. Heat the tack with the soldering iron and push it into the pilot hole until the top of the tack is just above the bottom of the hotend cap.
continue to install all of the tacks. You should have two tacks that arent linked together that you can solder to the leads that go to your printer controller board.
Now drill or melt a pilot holes into the hotend cap midway between each of the two tacks that form a pair, so that when you screw the brass screw into the hole it will bridge the tacks and complete a part of the circuit. Start the brass screw into the hole, but not too far. Now touch the soldering iron to the brass screw to slightly melt the plastic at the tip of the screw, so as you continue to screw it in it doesn't break the cap and cause it to delaminate.
Now change the setting in your firmware so that the switch setting for the probe switch is " normally closed".
Finally, if I haven't missed anything, you should be ready to go!
Hopefully you won't need the rubber band, but if your springs don't do a good enough job of keeping your contacts closed, it adds some extra tension.
Note: I intend to redesign this so that it is easier to put together, and not so much melting and drilling of plastic is involved.

description.text:
Umm... I'm going to reload this with the image oriented properly.... I do not recommend printing in the orientation pictured.... Anyway...I was looking for an ice scoop to keep from having to put my hands in the ice tray in my freezer (and constantly fumbling cubes onto the kitchen tile)... but all the scoops I were finding on thingiverse were either a) requiring a lot of support due to curves or b) had to be resized for my 13cmx13cm Davinci Jr tray and ended up being too tiny to be functional ....
...So I designed this scoop to have a blunt (but beveled) face to maximize scoop volume while keeping the overall dimensions compact. It's square shape makes for a quick and tidy build, no supports, no rafts needed. I print onto blue painters tape. This particular model was sized to fit into the side of the fridge's ice bucket without having to pull the tray out and away from the ice maker (8cm wide). I glued a magnet on the back so I could stick it on my fridge for convenience. It's not a fancy object, but it's a simple and quick build and it works really well both while scooping, and bringing the ice out of the fridge to your cup. Holds 5-8 large ice cubes, plenty for a glass of ice water.

Printer Brand:

XYZprinting

Printer:

da Vinci Jr. 2.0 Mix

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

Going from an all-in-one board (GT2560) to Mega+RAMPS left me with the problem of what to do about all my permanently-powered fans, as the GT2560 had dedicated fan sockets, and the RAMPS only gives you a 12V aux.
Additionally, I needed to power accessories, like fan controllers and so on.
And on top of that, I didn't want to have to buy anything special, so this was done on what could be printed, and salvaged from inside the house. It manages to be slick and exceedingly sketchy at the same time, somehow... :D

This can be used with normal PC fans, Dupont connectors, and with a small amount of persuasion, XH2.54, and the spacing is such that you can normally get away with combinations of the above.

In addition to the printed parts, you will need:
Soldering iron+solder.
Standard 2.54mm PCB pin headers - 10, split into 5 sets of two. It's easier if you keep the twos linked.
A paperclip or two.
Wiring to take power from your 12V-aux to the splitter. This can be twincore, individual stranded wires soldered direct, bought components, or do what I did and salvage a power lead from a two-pin fan.

Please note that I am not responsible for you blowing up your printers, setting your house on fire, or similar things. You're putting a positive and a ground fairly close together in the same box, and although I've tried to make the it solid and safe-ish (because I don't want to blow up -my- printer either), take care.

CEL

Printer:

Robox

No

Yes

30%

Push the pin headers through the holes in the top plate. Due to slicer behaviour and elephant foot, they -should- stay firmly in from friction-fit. Straighten and cut two lengths of paperclip wire, and solder to the outsides of each pair of pins, ensuring no solder bridges from one side to the other. Feed the power cabling into the two holes in the base, and solder to the pins closest to its end, then press-fit the two halves together. They should friction-fit.

You will now want to verify your wiring, mark a BIG "+" on the positive terminal side so you don't forget, and see if everything explodes when you plug it in. Good luck, and happy printing. :)

description.text:
Ever forget to grab plastic utensils on your lunch break? Yeah, me too. Don't worry, I got you covered! Instead of wasting valuable time trying to find something to eat your meal with, just pull one of these out!!
Keep one of these in your wallet or purse just in case!

They're ergonomically designed to work well even with their small form factor!

I've decided to add a version that has a spoon! (CC_cutlery-V2-KNIFE-SPOON)
I'm going to work on a spork next :)
UPDATE TWO
I've added a spoon/fork combo! (CC_cutlery-V3-SPOON-FORK)
I've also updated the names of the files to be a bit more descriptive, the files themselves are unchanged, just their names.
UPDATE THREE
The long awaited spork is here!!

This should probably be printed out of 'food safe' filament, but since they're not meant to be used every day, you should be okay to use a standard PLA (Do NOT use ABS).
But since I don't want anyone getting sick because of what I said,
PLEASE USE FOOD SAFE FILAMENT!!!

I'm listing this as "Work in progress" because I feel like the design could still be tweaked and made better.
If you have any ideas, please let me know!

title: Aldi Xfinity and Ryobi battery connector

description.text:
Holds an xfinity 2.0Ah or 4.0Ah battery, internal view https://imgur.com/a/Q3I3x

edit: also thanks to HowardB in comments, fits the Ryobi 18V batterys which look identical to your Aldi Xfinity ones:

CLB-1813X - 1300mAh
BAT1860X - 1500mAh
XB-3000 - 3000mAh

The later batterys hold Samsung 20Q inr's and are fitted with a charge display, at <$20 .. great value. I assume the controller specs have remained the same. Suspect the 4.0Ah cell has higher discharge max but do not own one yet.

Battery BMS cutoff current calculated at 25.3A, full charge 21.25V, discharge cutoff at 13.50V.

I wanted this to drive CNC stepper motors and controller, the retaining holes for the standard blue electrical spade crimps are 7mm diameter and hold quite firmly, so you might need to round the crimp base off with pliers to get it to fit snugly. The wire holes are 3mm and I used a heavy duty 10g silicon wire which was 3.5mm diameter, instead of drilling and weakening the plastic I used a warmed screwdriver blade to open the holes up a bit and with a press fit wire the blades are not even trying to move when unplugging the battery and line up quite well.
The clamp works the same as the drills etc, ie, you have to use the button on the pack to remove the battery.
The electrical blades do not go in as far as the tool blade pins but the clamping is done near the tip so length is no issue, seems to be an adequate connection.

Heard the model had issues so ran it through Netfabb and uploaded the fixed version also.

comments.text: Just a quick question, I have both a 2 and a 4 amp battery, the 2 amp starts the motor mower and the 4 amp powers my drill for long spells at a time. I was just wondering, if you could adapt the 4 amp battery pack to provide 12 volts, you could power a 3D printer for a short while, I figured you would get about an hour if you weren't running a heated bed, mind you that's me just thinking it in my head, in practice it may not be possible. You triggered that off when you mentioned CNC steppers, and I wondered if you could practically power a 3D printer off a battery pack, of course maybe you would need a car battery to get some good life out of a run, any thoughts on battery powered 3D printing? Also why did you strip down your battery pack? I seen it on your blog or whatever site you are on. Were you just curious or was it broken?
comments.author: hughee

comments.text:
I design electronics so I like to know whats inside things as I often learn something useful .. like a good little 5 cell BMS chip in this case :)
I wanted to know what current it could handle as well. I still want to pull apart a 4Ah one and see if the output current is higher than the 25.3A design for the 2.0Ah packs.
A 3D printer would almost certainly run the steppers off the 13-20V these packs provide quite happily, I have 2 printers, one is 12V and the other is 24V .. the drivers are generally fine, even the cheapest drivers are good to 30V or so, better ones to 45V, the filament heater is obviously the correct resistance for the available voltage so you might need to find a higher resistance one if the controller can't handle the current .. generally though the controller can handle a lot larger currents than the filament heater will need, so a PID retune is probably going to handle that.
The last thing is the low voltage regulator for the onboard micro etc, this might need to have its max voltage checked and make sure it does not overheat .. then the LEDs will be a little brighter, check the supply caps can handle the voltage etc .. but in general I would think a 12V control board will work ok on 20V, unless its a standard sort of arduino in which case 12V is about the max without adding a BEC or similar to bring the voltage down a bit for the micro regulator.

**The dimensions printed need a critical tweaking.***
As part of our garden railroad, I am building a water powered generator. The housing for the generator is being made out of a Lincoln Log set my wife gave me.
This will work fine, until the big bad wolf comes by and huffs and puffs.
Lincoln Logs everywhere.
Plan B
Put rubberbands around the corners of the Lincoln Logs.
Note to self:
Rubber Bands in sun are unreliable.
Might have just invented the catapult.
Now off on a treasure hunt to find all the missing Lincoln Logs, not wanting to step on any in the dark and ending up concussing myself.
Along comes Tronxy, a snowy midwinter afternoon
Made a fixture to either act as a wheel, be able to act as a guide to drill a bolt hole through the center of the Lincoln Log and they stay together.
You can even play catch with them.
A Tinker Toy to Lincoln Logs adapter is in the works to allow purchasing the Crane on the Log scaffold.

After two years of carrying this around I figure its about time to share my design.
I designed this in 2016 to carry around a spare battery for my GS5. The first design was completely square, I had issues with this as it tore holes in my pants. After revising 6 to 7 times this was the final product.

All edges are round to allow for easy carry in pockets.
Simple two piece latch design.
Slot in bottom of case to catch feet of battery.
Hole in back to make easy removal of battery.
Tight tolerances for little sliding room.
1mm of space at top for easy battery removal.

ALL .PRT FILES INCLUDED FOR CUSTOMIZATION OF CASES
I love these cases, I carry one everyday, and I hope you will too!
Feel free to tip your makers!

I was looking for a way to add a QI charger to my 2007 Toyota Camry cup holder. Wepollock's replacement part (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2515329) worked really well for the base, and I added the QI Powerbot stand by rroyter (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1051668) to the back cup hole for the QI side of things. The QI stand was a little too short for an iPhone X to get charge, so I lengthened the arm a little, and I scaled it down by 2% to make the Powerbot QI charger fit a little better with my print. After print, I put a little tape on the back to keep the Powerbot there and it works like a charm.

I used ABS (although my PLA test print worked fine) at .2MM with supports for the arms.

Will post final pictures at some point.
