description.text:
This is a Three-Axis-Router.
I designed it during my bachelor thesis.
It acts as a 3D-printer and CNC-mill/drill, but other tools like a laser are possible.
The printhead is detachable and can be replaced by a mount for a rotational tool.
For milling I used a machine manufactured by proxxon with an extension, but by modifying the attached .scad-files you can design a mount for your own device.

In the current configuration the machine reaches a maximal speed of 24mm/s. At higher speeds it loses steps. Furthermore it is very noisy. You can treat these problems by using better stepper drivers than I did.

The frame has to be strengthened by MDF-plates. Otherwise it cannot resist the forces.
Further instructions of assembly you will find in the dreiachsenrouter.scad.
The machine should be able to handle a tool with the weight of 1kg.

I use an Arduino-Mega2560 controller with a ramps-shield, running Marlin. The configuration is attached.
As display mount I modified a design by Trigubovich.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1116163

My bachelor thesis can be found here:
http://www.uni-oldenburg.de/svs/lehre/abschlussarbeiten/2017/entwurf-und-implementierung-eines-dreiachsenrouters/
It is written in german.

I will add more pictures in the following weeks. Feel free to ask questions and improve or remix my designs.

A video of the machine plays music can be found here:
https://youtu.be/zJX3pELtMns

description.text:
The sections of the 120-cell (a four-dimensional regular polytope built out of 120 dodecahedral cells) as cut by three-dimensional hyperplanes parallel to one cell and intersecting sets of vertices.

The sections go from an initial cell at the "south pole" (Section VIII) to the "equator" (Section XIV), labeled as in the figures from Alicia Boole Stott's 1900 paper "On certain Series of Sections of the Regular Four-dimensional Hypersolids." Stott herself was the first to build models of these sections, but hers were made from card stock. Sections VIII and IX are dodecahedra, Section X an icosidodecahedron, and Section XIII a rhombicosidodecahedron, but the files are all to scale as sections of the 120-cell.

The assemblage of dodecahedra shown in the images represents the a partial "net" for the 120-cell, built from 75 copies of Section VIII, with the dodecahedral cell forming the "south pole" at the center, and the red cells around the periphery forming the "equator." To complete the net, another copy of this partial net, excluding the "equatorial" cells, would have to be attached. The sections only go to the equator as well; beyond Section XIV, the sections would repeat in reverse order from XIII to VIII.

The models are all colored consistently, with the cell at the "south pole" being uncolored, those around it yellow, the next layers green, blue, and red, in that order. Each polygonal face is a section of a dodecahedral cell. Where the faces shared by the yellow cells and the blue cells appear as the pentagons in Section XI, a choice had to be made for face color.

Created after reading Coxeter's Regular Polytopes.

Printer:

NWA3D A31

I constructed the concentric sections in GeoGebra... ...used transformations to create the set of vertices for each section as a list... ...copied the list into the GeoGebra spreadsheet, transferred it to Word, then Excel, then Notepad, with suitable modifications along the way... ...saved as an .obj file in Notepad, imported it into Blender, and used the convex hull tool to create the section. Somewhat crude and convoluted, but it's the quickest way I could figure out to get an .stl file out of a .ggb file. No doubt this workflow will soon be rendered obsolete, once GeoGebra includes a way of exporting a 3D file as an .obj or .stl file.

author: hansms

description.text:
Hi friends,

I don't know for you but me... I have a problem with my button cells. Many size, many uses and always the reference written for top 10 lynx eye people! Not easy to find the one I need and to spare place at the same time.
I searched a ready made object on different sites but nothing was exactly what I wanted. So I decided to make my own thing.
My functional specifications were :

  • A box (not only open cradle),
  • The name of battery on the box,
  • Pack of 10 batteries,
  • Usable with alkaline (AGxx type) or Lithium (CRxx) batteries,
  • If possible, a cradle to group boxes despite the different box sizes.

And with the help of the great Supercalifragilistic sorcerer, I made this Button Cells Holder, fondly named BCH or Bisch.

The use is easy as for a 5 years kid : choose your reference and print it.
For alkaline batteries there are many type of references, I used AG (ie AG1). There are many sites with reference compatibilities (one of my best because no ads and fast display is : http://altert.family.free.fr/pere/tcpiles.html)
For lithium, I used CR because this reference gives the size (CR2320 is 23mm diameter and 2mm width)

The same STL file contains the cradle and the cover to limit the number of files. If you need to print only one of the two pieces, you can use the "split object" function of Repetier-Host (or of your slicer).

I added the cradle for boxes. I propose many sizes. All you have to do is to measure the total width of your boxes and to choose the cradle the nearest of that size.

Of course there are many more references and you may need other sizes of box cradle or battery reference. Feel free to ask and I'll try to upload the thing you need.

Due to the small size of boxes, I tried to optilmize the printing. The inner wall thickness is 0.8mm and in rapport with the nozzle size (0.4mm for me). If you have printing problems with other nozzle sizes, contact me. If necessary, I'll make a version for another nozzle size.

Not support needed, 10% infill, nothing complicated in printing.

I hope you'll like this BCH.

Last thing. Don't be surprised to find the battery reference on the side of the cover and not on the top. It is only to allow a no support printing.

Bonjour chez vous.

List of button cells supported :

BCH for lithium : CR1025, CR1130, CR1216, CR1220, CR1612, CR1620, CR1625, CR1616, CR1632, CR2012, CR2016, CR2025, CR2032, CR2320, CR2325, CR2330, CR2354, CR2430, CR2450, CR2477, CR3032

BCH for alkaline : AG1, AG2, AG3, AG4, AG5, AG6, AG7, AG8, AG9, AG10, AG11, AG12, AG13

Cradle for boxes : 60mm, 85mm, 100mm and 150mm
I used a marker to paint the references but if you have a bicolor printer...

description.text:
a maze

Rev. 01: Added top cover. 01/02/2018

A compilation of stackable mazes. The main goal is to travel the ball through the first layer to de last one.

It can be played with the help of a printed sheet with the layouts/maps (also provided) or with no aid trying to map the maze without peaking (really difficult).

There are several maps with different levels of difficulty. More to be added in the future.

This puzzle was designed to be used with a Ø9.5mm steel ball (from a ball bearing). To use another ball with a different diameter, you'll need to scale the parts.
Example:
Ø19mm ball
The scale factor would be 19/9.5=2.

I hope you enjoy the puzzle.

description.text:
A case to display to sit on a desk or bookcase. Design features a two pice 3D printed setup and utilizes two pieces of Acrylic or Plexiglass/Lexan to provide a see through display mount. Since the plastic windows are held in place by Nuts & Bolts/Machine Screws, assembly and disassembly is easy and repeatable. Items inside the case can be held in place by glue to the back piece of plastic or via pressure from a the plastic windows on the object.  Alternatively the objects can remain loose and move around when shaken.  
Current design provides a 3 inch square working space that accommodates items .215 inches thick (loose fit) or slightly more (pressure fit).

Step 1: Measure and Modify
Begin by measuring the object(s) you want to place in the display case. The current design files give a 3 inch square space (with rounded corners) that is .215 inches thick. Adjust these figures to your own desire. Key is the thickness of the mount itself. If you want to have your object(s) stay in place by friction than the mount would need to be slightly thinner than the object itself. Alternatively if you want things to be loose than you want to ensure the thickness is big enough to prevent things from sticking. When modifying keep in mind any empty space you want. Also note the base width should match the width of the mount, adjust accordingly. The base does not include the three screw holes that would be necessary to attach it to the mount. If your comfortable that these will print well add them now (make sure to measure correctly). Otherwise you will need to drill these by hand later. The original 123d Design file is included for your moding use. For more information 123d Design or to download the software visit: http://www.123dapp.com/design. Step 2: Supplies and Printing
Print the two parts on a 3D Printer. If you modify the files for your own use, make sure to create new STL files with your modifications. This is easier from the 123d Design Desktop app then the web interface. In addition to the 3d Printed parts you will need:
1) Plexiglass or Acrylic. You will need enough to cut two windows the size of the mount. For the included STL files this is 4 Inches square. A .080 Thickness worked well with the included STL files, providing a relatively flush line with the base. 2) Machine Screws/Bolts and nuts. For the included STL files #4 Machine Screws fit well (though a bit tight in the drilled holes). Keep in mind length (which would be the thickness of the mount, plus the thickness of the plastic times two, plus room to screw on the nuts with extra to spare). For the included files, I used 5 #4-40 X 3/4 inch machine screws for the top five holes. For the three holes that will be on the bottom #4-40 X 1 Inch machine screws worked well. These bottom screws have to also go through holes in the based (drilled later). Step 3: Cut the Windows
Next you will need to cut the windows and drill the corresponding holes so the screws /bolts can go trough the windows. For instructions on working with acrylic visit: http://www.plaskolite.com/Fabrication/Acrylic/Cutting-And-Machining. For the holes a 1/8 (.125) diameter worked was used and works well with the #4 Machine Screws used. To line up the holes I used the already printed mount as a template which I held in place with clamps. This worked ok at best (I still managed to get mis-aligned holes). Drill presses are recommended. While at it the base was designed without the holes necessary to attach to the base. This was done to avoid any overhang and to ensure I get the alignment right. If you did not add the holes in the design before printing you will need to drill these out now. Step 4: Assemble
Put the pieces together and screw/bolt tight. It should go Plexiglass/Acrylic, Mount & Object(s), Plexiglass/Acrylic, and base. Refer to the pictures for visuals.

title: Protection for weapons 2.0 (for Latinamerica and Europe) (CANCELED) / Protección para armas 2.0 (para Américalatina y Europa) (CANCELADO)

description.text:
Protection for weapons 2.0 (for Latinamerica and Europe) (CANCELED) / Protección para armas 2.0 (para Américalatina y Europa) (CANCELADO)

Siento comunicar que el ingeniero de armas y mi amigo Ing. Eduardo Wernik que estábamos diseñado el proyecto "Protección para armas 2.0" se dejo de cooperar por fuerza mayor en su trabajos mas importante en la fuerza armada uruguaya y lamentamos informales que este proyecto ha sido cancelado.

Mi idea es poner dos metales (soldador) como sándwiches y que el "relleno" un ABS que trabe la gatillo con 2 metales en forma de L tenga un candado.

Haciendo así que no se pueda activar accidentalmente. ejemplo: un niño jugando con el arma.
Y el metal protege contra martillos o destornillador el "relleno" impreso en ABS...

Lo siento por este fracaso pero entiendo a mi amigo Ing. que es por fuerza mayor.

Adjunto los archivos que son borradores porque el tamaño no esta definido y tampoco supervisado por el Ing.

Si alguien tiene bolas y experiencia para hacer esto espero que le será útil mi idea y esta toltamente libre de editar y modificar.

Gracias Saludos a todos

I am sorry to inform you that the weapons engineer and my friend Ing. Eduardo Wernik, who were designing the project "Protection for weapons 2.0", stopped cooperating by force majeure in their most important work in the armed forces.
Uruguayan and regret that this project has been canceled.

My idea is to put two metals (soldering iron) as sandwiches and that the "stuffing" an ABS that holds the trigger with 2 metals in the form of L has a padlock.

Doing so that can not be activated accidentally. example: a child playing with the weapon.
And the metal protects against hammers or screwdrivers the "filling" printed in ABS ...

I'm sorry for this failure but I understand my friend Ing. Who is by force majeure.

I attach the files that are drafts because the size is not defined and also not supervised by Ing.

If someone has balls and experience to do this, I hope that my idea will be useful and that he is completely free to edit and modify.

Thanks greetings to all

author: rdhoke

print_settings.Notes:: I also made two standoffs which go on the heatsink so the fan and mount sit straight.

description.text:
I printed the BLTouch mount by OderWat and used it for several months printing PLA. When I upgraded to ABS the heat from the extruder started to warp my PLA upgrades for the ANET A8. The arm on the mount also broke and the mount was difficult to remove because one of the mounting screws was blocked. So I redesigned the BLTouch mount to have wider arms, more support structure and also moved the BLTouch towards the extruder 8mm so both screws can be accessed without taking the BLTouch off. I cut the heat sink in half so I could see the nozzle when loading filament.

Set the X & Y offsets for this mount in the firmware:


define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -38
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER -9
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

I also defined the probing locations so the extruder does not crash to the far right when probing.

define LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15
define RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 175
define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15
define BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 170

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed this in ABS so it could withstand higher temps. PLA will eventually warp if you start printing ABS.

I also made two standoffs which go on the heatsink so the fan and mount sit straight.

I used the long screws which are included with the ANET A8 kit for mounting. I added four small washers, 2 for the BLTouch and 2 for the mount itself.

My block cooling fan broke and I have another one on order. If you exclude the fan you will need shorter screws. (I'm only using the fan housing for spacing in the pictures)

You will need to adjust your extruder nozzle heighth by screwing it in or out so the BLTouch probe is far enough from the build plate when retracked and so your nozzle does not crash into the build plate with doing a G28/G29 command.
